name: Literary Twosomes Online Trivia | Mixed Literature | 10 Questions

questions.text: What author based one of his works upon Shakespeare's characters of Rosencrantz and Guildenstern?
questions.explanation:
Tom Stoppard.

	'Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead' is the play.

questions.text: Speaking of Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, in what play do they originally appear?
questions.explanation:
Hamlet.

	Minor characters in Shakespeare's play.

questions.text: Daedalus and Icarus are characters in a mythical story. What caused problems for Icarus during his escape and flight?
questions.correct: He flew too close to the sun
options: He got involved with bad company
He got lost by following the wrong path
questions.explanation:
He flew too close to the sun.

	The heat of the sun melted his wax wings.

questions.text: What is the most prominent feature of the relationship between Sidney Carton and Charles Darnay?
questions.correct: Strong physical resemblance of one to the other
questions.explanation:
Strong physical resemblance of one to the other.

	'A Tale of Two Cities'. 'It is a far, far better thing I do ...'

Burdick and Lederer.

	Nordhoff and Hall did 'Mutiny on the Bounty'; Knebel and Bailey did 'Seven Days in May'.

questions.text: Oscar Wilde's life was forever changed by his relationship with this individual.
questions.explanation:
Alfred Douglas.

	His relationship with 'Bosie' led to his trials, imprisonment, sense of betrayal, etc.

questions.text: Which two poets had an intense relationship which led to one taking a shot at the other?
questions.explanation:
Verlaine and Rimbaud.

	Rimbaud finished with literature at an early age.

questions.text: Who was the diabolical enemy of Sherlock Holmes?
questions.explanation:
Moriarty.

	Valjean is from 'Les Miserables'; Myshkin is from 'The Idiot'. Quasimodo is from 'Hunchback of Notre Dame'.

questions.text: Which work belongs to Christopher Marlowe?
questions.explanation:
Hero and Leander.

	'Stella' is Philip Sidney; the other two are Shakespeare.

questions.text: It's not possible to think of Dr Jekyll without also thinking of Mr. Hyde. Who is the author?
questions.explanation:
Robert Louis Stevenson.

	One of many popular works by RLS.
